Virtual Reality technology has primarily been used as a training tool for disaster preparedness, but there have been some examples of VR technology being used in actual disaster situations. For example, during the 2017 Hurricane Harvey in Texas, the United States Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) used VR technology to develop real-time flood maps using satellite imagery, which allowed emergency responders to better coordinate rescue operations and evacuate people from areas at risk of catastrophic flooding. Furthermore, there have been some examples of using VR technology to remotely monitor and collect data in disaster situations, which can be used to aid in the disaster response, such as using drones with VR technology to survey and monitor disaster areas. 

Despite these examples, it is important to recognize that VR technology may have some limitations if used in actual disaster situations. For instance, VR technology relies on expensive and specialized equipment, which may not be available in disaster-affected areas. Additionally, the technical limitations such as low battery life, limited connectivity, and harsh environmental conditions may make it difficult to use VR technology in such scenarios. Therefore, while VR technology may have potential for use in actual disaster situations, its use would need to be carefully evaluated on a case-by-case basis based on the specific needs and context of the disaster.
